pullRequest.body:
This PR proves KÅ‘nig's infinity lemma in terms of covers in a strongly atomic order, and it gives a common formulation for directed systems, which is useful for applications such as Ramsey theory. 

One of the things we needed is a `Fintype` instance for `RelEmbedding r s`. This would have caused a bad diamond with 
`SimpleGraph.Hom.instFintype`, so instead we remove the latter and provide their common generalization `RelHom.instFintype` in `Fintype.Pi`.

---

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

using the following format:

```suggestion
noncomputable instance _root_.RelEmbedding.instFintype {Î± Î²} [Fintype Î±] [Fintype Î²]
```

This is really confusing notation. Can't you simply use
```suggestion
    Infinite (Î£ a, Î² a) :=
```

If I do that, the infoview still shows the original notation, which is why I stated it that way. 

If the notation with the Sigma is less confusing, the pp should be changed to reflect that, and it's out of scope here.

At least, don't add extraneous brackets
```suggestion
    Infinite ((a : Î±) Ã— Î² a) :=
```

```suggestion
## TODO

Actually formulate the lemma as a statement about graphs.
```
Please don't indent docstrings by default
Seems like there are more docstrings to unindent

```suggestion
/-- **KÅ‘nig's infinity lemma**: if each element in an infinite well-founded order with minimum
```

```suggestion
    âŸ¨_, (exists_covby_infinite_Ici_of_infinite_Ici p.2 (hfin p.1)).choose_spec.2âŸ©
```

```suggestion
  rintro âŸ¨f, -âŸ© âŸ¨g, -âŸ©; simp
```
Can you provide the `WellFoundedGT` and `StrictAnti` versions? Should be three more lemmas in total
This is a bad instance since it causes a non-defeq diamond with the existing `SimpleGraph.Hom.instFintype`. Can you generalise `SimpleGraph.Hom.instFintype` to arbitrary `RelHom` instead?

```suggestion
    Infinite ((a : Î±) Ã— Î² a) :=
```

You can also keep a version of your non-instance, but the following can be made an instance
```suggestion
instance Infinite.sigma_of_right {Î² : Î± â†’ Type*} [Nonempty Î±] [âˆ€ a, Infinite (Î² a)] :
```
I find it a bit weird to have these lemmas in a file whose name doesn't mention `Cover`. Maybe the whole file could be renamed to `Order.Cover.WellFounded` (and `Order.Cover` to `Order.Cover.Basic`)?

I'm not sure about this - to me, covering is enough of a vanilla notion that it is fine for it to come up in files where it isn't the main focus, and conversely, the infinity lemma isn't really at heart about covering (its usual formulation makes no mention of orderings at all). Renaming the file would be misclassifying its contents.

Sure, but `theorem exists_covby_of_lt (hab : a < b) : âˆƒ x, a â‹– x âˆ§ x â‰¤ b` _really_ looks like an API lemma for `CovBy`.

Maybe you could move it to `Order.Cover`
Irrelevant changes
These results can live in `Fintype/Card`, and then don't need any import increase.
Thanks for this! If this was the only issue, I think this should be good to merge.
What is the story here? Could you document its removal (rather, its motion to Fintype/Pi) in the PR description?
Done

```suggestion
    (hfin : âˆ€ i a, {b : Î± (i+1) | Ï€ (Nat.le_add_right i 1) b = a}.Finite) :
```

Too many brackets, seemingly
```suggestion
    (Ï€_trans : âˆ€ â¦ƒi j kâ¦„ (hij : i â‰¤ j) (hjk : j â‰¤ k) a, Ï€ hij (Ï€ hjk a) = Ï€ (hij.trans hjk) a)
```

I think it would be a bit nicer to follow the category theory library here and state preservation of identity before preservation of composition
```suggestion
    (Ï€_refl : âˆ€ â¦ƒiâ¦„ (a : Î± i), Ï€ rfl.le a = a)
    (Ï€_trans : âˆ€ â¦ƒi j kâ¦„ (hij : i â‰¤ j) (hjk : j â‰¤ k) a, (Ï€ hij) (Ï€ hjk a) = Ï€ (hij.trans hjk) a)
```

```suggestion
      rintro âŸ¨i, aâŸ© âŸ¨j, bâŸ© âŸ¨hij : i â‰¤ j, hab : Ï€ hij b = aâŸ© âŸ¨hji : j â‰¤ i, hba : Ï€ hji a = bâŸ©
```

It would be worth explaining how this is a specialization of `nonempty_sections_of_finite_cofiltered_system`, but which has much lighter dependencies (that one goes through a category theory version of the compactness theorem, `TopCat.nonempty_limitCone_of_compact_t2_cofiltered_system`).

A less actionable suggestion: I think that this paragraph sort of apologizes for it not being the graph version, which doesn't seem necessary, since I think more often than not people use graphs as a way to organize the idea conceptually, vs the graph theoretic version being what people mean. I suppose I'd more likely think of it in terms of chains in a relation than order theory though, so that's worth explaining.

Regarding `exists_seq_forall_proj_of_forall_finite`, it seems like "main results" is justifying it as being useful for applications of Ramsey theory, but to me this sort of is what I think of when I think of Konig's lemma. It's the more category theoretic version. ("projective limits of nonempty finite types are nonempty"). Could you mention that this is the projective limit formulation?
I wasn't aware of the category-theoretic connections. I have written something, but I don't follow your last paragraph, and I may have missed the point. If I have, can you suggest a phrasing?
@kmill I ended up here while trying to figure out what is this reference to `nonempty_sections_of_finite_cofiltered_system`, which doesn't exist?

I thought I remembered someone refactoring this, but it still seems to be around @digama0: https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/CofilteredSystem.html#nonempty_sections_of_finite_cofiltered_system
oops, I guess I messed up my search somehow.

Why is the Subsingleton assumption necessary? Maybe it's easier to bootstrap the theorem by having `Î± 0` be a singleton, but the full theorem shouldn't need this since you can restrict the inverse system to the preimages of that element.
```suggestion
theorem exists_seq_forall_proj_of_forall_finite {Î± : â„• â†’ Type*}
```

It's false if the subsingleton assumption is removed; for instance, take `Î± i = â†‘(Ici i : Set â„•)` where `Ï€ hij âŸ¨x, _âŸ© = âŸ¨x, _âŸ©`. 

It is true with the weaker assumption `Finite (Î± 0)`, but that version seems a little artificial to me, since it just amounts to cutting off the root of the tree. Should I still generalize it that way?

Ah right, I forgot that this Ici example applies here, even if you relax finiteness just at the root.

I guess `Subsingleton` is fine, but it would be nice to have the finiteness condition be more uniform. One way to think about it is that there's a singleton "`Î± (-1)`" that augments the system.
Yes - that's the right intuition but awkward to formalize. I'll mark this as resolved, if that's good with you.

Let's please make it more general. If you change your `theorem exists_seq_forall_proj_of_forall_finite` to `private lemma exists_seq_forall_proj_of_forall_finite_aux` then here's 
```lean
theorem exists_seq_forall_proj_of_forall_finite {Î± : â„• â†’ Type*} [Finite (Î± 0)]
    [âˆ€ i, Nonempty (Î± i)] (Ï€ : {i j : â„•} â†’ (hij : i â‰¤ j) â†’ Î± j â†’ Î± i)
    (Ï€_refl : âˆ€ â¦ƒiâ¦„ (a : Î± i), Ï€ rfl.le a = a)
    (Ï€_trans : âˆ€ â¦ƒi j kâ¦„ (hij : i â‰¤ j) (hjk : j â‰¤ k) a, Ï€ hij (Ï€ hjk a) = Ï€ (hij.trans hjk) a)
    (hfin : âˆ€ i a, {b : Î± (i+1) | Ï€ (Nat.le_add_right i 1) b = a}.Finite) :
    âˆƒ f : (i : â„•) â†’ Î± i, âˆ€ â¦ƒi jâ¦„ (hij : i â‰¤ j), Ï€ hij (f j) = f i := by
  let Î±' : â„• â†’ Type _
    | 0 => PUnit
    | i + 1 => Î± i
  let Ï€' : {i j : â„•} â†’ (h : i â‰¤ j) â†’ Î±' j â†’ Î±' i
    | 0, 0, _, x => x
    | 0, _, _, _ => PUnit.unit
    | i + 1, j + 1, h, x => Ï€ (Nat.pred_le_pred h) x
  have (i : â„•) : Nonempty (Î±' i) := by cases i <;> infer_instance
  have âŸ¨f', h'âŸ© := exists_seq_forall_proj_of_forall_finite_aux Ï€' ?rfl ?trans ?fin
  Â· use fun i => f' (i + 1)
    intros i j h
    exact h' (Nat.succ_le_succ h)
  case rfl =>
    rintro (_ | i)
    Â· simp
    Â· apply Ï€_refl
  case trans =>
    rintro (_ | i) (_ | j) (_ | k) <;> (try simp; done)
    simpa using fun hij => Ï€_trans hij
  case fin =>
    rintro (_ | i)
    Â· simp [Î±', finite_univ]
    Â· apply hfin
```

There's probably also a way to modify the original proof to make use of `WithBot ((i : â„•) Ã— Î± i)`, but there's no need for going down that path (and I didn't manage to do it myself).
I found a cleaner way with no auxiliary lemma. (Just pick a base element with infinitely many things above it, then apply the version of Konig with that element at the bottom).

That's great! It's nice that it didn't need much of a change to the proof.

(In my formalization of Konig's lemma, the first step was to restrict to the "very extendable" elements in every set â€” those elements with infinitely many things above them â€” and then show that each such element is the image of such an element. Then it's an application of choice. Seems like a similar principle here, but just for the base case?)

I took a pass at this:
```text
KÅ‘nig's infinity lemma is most often stated as a graph theory result:
every infinite, locally finite connected graph contains an infinite path.
It has links to computability and proof theory, and it has a number of formulations.

In practice, most applications are not to an abstract graph,
but to a concrete collection of objects that are organized in a graph-like way,
often where the graph is a rooted tree representing a graded order.
In fact, the lemma is in fact most easily stated and proved
in terms of covers in a strongly atomic order rather than a graph;
in this setting, the proof is almost trivial.

A common formulation of KÅ‘nig's lemma is in terms of directed systems,
with the grading explicitly represented using an `â„•`-indexed family of types,
which we also provide in this module.
This is a specialization of the much more general `nonempty_sections_of_finite_cofiltered_system`,
which goes through topology and category theory,
but it is stated and proved independently with much fewer dependencies.

We leave the explicitly graph-theoretic version of the statement as TODO.

## Main Results

* `exists_seq_covby_of_forall_covby_finite` : KÅ‘nig's lemma for strongly atomic orders.

* `exists_orderEmbedding_covby_of_forall_covby_finite` : KÅ‘nig's lemma, where the sequence
  is given as an `OrderEmbedding` instead of a function.

* `exists_orderEmbedding_covby_of_forall_covby_finite_of_bot` : KÅ‘nig's lemma where the sequence
  starts at the minimum of an infinite type.

* `exist_seq_forall_proj_of_forall_finite` : KÅ‘nig's lemma for inverse systems,
  proved using the above applied to an order on a sigma-type `(i : â„•) Ã— Î± i`.
```
Thanks!

```suggestion
is the limit of the `Î± i`.

See also `nonempty_sections_of_finite_cofiltered_system`. -/
```

A small style note you can ignore is that `have` lots you drop the identifier completely:
```suggestion
  have : IsStronglyAtomic Î±s := by
```
I use the underscore because I don't like the brightly coloured `this` in the infoview for instances. Is the underscore considered bad style?
